These consultations will build on the framework outlined in December 2011 by the United States-Canada Beyond the Border Action Plan, which was announced by Canadian Prime Minister Stephen Harper and US President Barack Obama. The consultations are being conducted with two goals in mind: to get feedback regarding the Action Plan, and to identify new ways in which cross-border business can be facilitated for short- and mid-term goals.

Consultations will be held in Washington, D.C. and Toronto, Ontario. Comments will be accepted by private businesses and other stakeholders until June 15, 2012. Minister Kenney believes talks will be productive, stating that `Billions of dollars worth of goods and hundreds of thousands of people cross our shared border every day. We want to hear directly brom businesses on both sides of the border about how cross-border business travel could improve. We especially want to hear fresh ideas`.

item.title: New Permanent Residence Card Direct Mail-Out Pilot Program
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Beginning April 20, 2012, most permanent residents who require permanent resident (PR) cards will no longer have to pick up these cards at a Citizenship and Immigration Canada office. Instead, through a new pilot project, they will be able to receive their cards by mail.

item.title: Federal Internship for Newcomers Program Expands to Private Businesses
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: The Government of Canada has partnered with two leading private Canadian businesses to develop and expand the Federal Internship for Newcomers Program (FIN).

item.title: Federal Skilled Worker Cap Reached
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: As of yesterday, May 8, 2012, the maximum number of 10,000 Federal Skilled Worker applications has been reached. This cap on applications has been put in place for individuals applying under one of the 29 eligible occupations being targeted by Citizenship and Immigration Canada.

item.title: Ontario Extends Backlog Reduction Deadlines
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: The Ontario Provincial Nominee Program (PNP) has extended its deadline for selected applicants to apply through the Federal Skilled Worker Backlog Reduction Pilot Program. The deadline has been adjusted from May 4 to May 31, 2012.

item.title: Saskatchewan Businesses Hire 280 Irish Workers
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Businesses in Saskatchewan have hired over 280 skilled workers from Ireland. This is a direct result of a March 2012 recruitment mission, in which provincial officials and representatives from 27 Saskatchewan employers traveled to Ireland in search of employees.

item.title: Accelerated Labour Market Opinion Program Announced Today
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Employment and Social Development Canada (ESDC) announced today plans for a new Accelerated Labour Market Opinion (A-LMO) initiative. This initiative is effective from April 25, 2012.

item.title: Saskatchewan Seeks to Raise Provincial Nominee Limit
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: The Government of Saskatchewan has appealed to Federal authorities for the right to raise the amount of immigrants the province receives each year.

item.title: Consultations to Begin for New "Start Up" Entrepreneur Visa
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Canadian Immigration and Culture Minister, Jason Kenney, announced today that consultations have begun regarding the possible creation of a new program for immigrant entrepreneurs.

item.title: Minister Kenney Announces Proposed Changes to Canadian Experience Class
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Citizenship and Immigration Canada (CIC) announced today that Canadian Experience Class applicants who are currently residing in Canada as Temporary Foreign Workers will soon see their permanent residency applications expedited.

item.title: Language Testing to be Required for Some Provincial Nominees
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Speaking in Saskatchewan, the Canadian Minister of Immigration and Cultural Communities, Jason Kenney, stated that some applicants to Provincial Nominee Programs (PNPs) will be required to prove English or French language capabilities before submitting their immigration applications.

item.title: New Federal Skilled Worker Category to be Created for Skilled Trades
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: The Canadian Minister of Citizenship and Immigration, Jason Kenney, announced today plans to streamline the application process for skilled tradespersons seeking entry to Canada.

item.title: New Procedures Announced to Assess Foreign Credentials
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: On March 28, 2012, Jason Kenney, the Canadian Minister of Citizenship, Immigration, and Multiculturalism, announced major changes to the ways in which foreign skilled workers will have their education credentials assessed before arriving to Canada.

item.title: Breaking News: Government to Return Pre-2008 Applications
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: The Government of Canada announced on March 29, 2012 a plan to reduce the backlog of Federal Skilled Worker (FSW) applications by returning all applications and government fees submitted prior to February 27, 2008. This will amount to a total of almost 300,000 returned applications, as well as approximately $130 million in refunded government processing fees.

item.title: Citizenship and Immigration Canada Announces New Immigration Targets
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Every year, Citizenship and Immigration Canada (CIC) sets immigration targets to meet the Canadian government’s economic, family reunification, and humanitarian goals. 2012 will see a large increase in the issuance of visas from overseas, with total documents rising from 217,800 in 2011 to a projected 255,100 for this year.

item.title: Important Changes to Quebec Immigration Programs Announced
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: The Quebec Government announced yesterday a comprehensive plan to reduce processing times for permanent residency applicants to Quebec.

item.title: Best places for Canadian newcomers to work
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description:
A list of the top 100 employers for immigrants to Canada has been announced by Mediacorp and published in the Globe and Mail.

These employers were ranked by their recruiting efforts of recent immigrants, advertising job vacancies in multicultural media or having a similarly targeted dedicated website, recognizing foreign credentials, and training, language improvement, as well as internship initiatives.

item.title: Western provinces seek greater authority
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description:
Severe labour shortages in Western provinces have resulted in some provincial leaders calling for radical changes in immigration procedures.

Western provinces are largely in the midst of a job boom, which is being hindered by a lack of available and qualified workers to fill new positions.

item.title: Immigration Minister talks of aggressive moves to reduce backlog
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description:
Canadian Immigration Minister Jason Kenney suggested Wednesday the possibility of legislating away Canada’s backlog of immigration applications.

"We’re looking at all options for dealing with these backlogs… It’s not fair to [applicants] and it’s not fair to our economy," said Kenney.

item.title: New sponsorship restriction aims to reduce marriage fraud
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description:
In an effort to cut down on spousal sponsorship fraud, Citizenship and Immigration Canada (CIC) has put into action a new requirement where any new immigrant to Canada sponsored by a spouse or partner must have permanent residency (PR) status for five years before they themselves can sponsor a new spouse or partner from abroad.

This new requirement is effective immediately for new immigration applications under the Family Class category.

item.title: More action on Alberta’s labour shortage dilemma
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: A newly formed group called the Alberta Coalition for Action on Labour Shortage (ACALS) is pushing the federal government of Canada to amend immigration policies to address a significant labour shortage.

item.title: Preparing for the Quebec Selection Interview
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Applicants in the Quebec Skilled Worker (QSW) program may be required to attend an interview with a Quebec immigration officer.

item.title: Quebec employers no longer must recruit locally to hire foreign workers for range of jobs
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: While the Quebec Facilitated IT program came to an end on February 24th, the 7 affected professions are now part of a newly announced facilitated labour market assessment process. The new process, in effect now, includes a much broader range of 44 occupations, both in high tech and from other fields. It is an accelerated way for employers to hire foreign workers in Quebec, which importantly does not require employers to show local recruitment efforts.

item.title: Alberta boom continues to tap tight labour market
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: A shortage of labour was cited by a roundtable of energy companies in Alberta as their key business challenge. Easing immigration rules has been put forward as a possible partial solution.

item.title: Greeks looking to Canada as immigration option
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description:
Two sources in the past week reported a potential influx of Greek immigrants which could be on their way to Canada.

News1130 in Vancouver, and Metro News in Calgary, reported that these respective city’s Hellenic organizations have both fielded a huge increase of calls from people in Greece with interest in immigrating to Canada.

item.title: Montreal best city in Canada for university students
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description:
Montreal was just ranked the best city for university students in Canada, and the 10th best in the world.

The survey, conducted by the British firm QS, has Montreal beating out Chicago and New York City, and just behind Paris, London and Boston. Montreal scored so highly based heavily on its quality of life and number of international students.

item.title: The Success of Manitoba’s Provincial Nominee Program
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: While Canada is a large and diverse country, traditionally newcomers tended to settle in immigrant enclaves like Toronto, Vancouver, and Montreal. The situation is changing, however, as immigration programs like the popular Manitoba Provincial Nominee Program become more of an attraction.

item.title: Black History Month continues to be celebrated nation-wide
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description:
As mid-February approaches, Canada continues to celebrate Black history until the end of the month.

Black History Month started as an American tradition, originally referred to as ‘Negro History Week’ and lasting for this shorter time span. It was expanded to a full month and celebrated for the duration of February ever since 1976.

item.title: Atlantic Canada’s growth on the upswing too
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description:
All four of Canada’s Atlantic provinces have seen their population growth rate increase according to Canadian census numbers released last week.

Growth rate increases have been largely attributed to both increased immigration to the Atlantic provinces, and a better rate of retaining these immigrants in the region.

item.title: Hold ended on Iranian investor immigration affected by sanctions
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description:
Iranian immigrants coming to Canada via one of its investor programs can once again transfer required funds between Iran and Canada, as of January 25th, 2012.

Last November 22nd, the Canadian Ministry of Foreign Affairs and International Trade – as part of sanctions against Iran – made it illegal to transfer more than CDN $40,000 to Canada from Iran without a permit for the specified transaction issued by the Minister of Foreign Affairs John Baird.

item.title: Census shows Canada growing fastest in G8 thanks to immigration
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: The first 2012 Canadian census numbers were released today highlighting Canada’s population growth.

item.title: Updates made to National Occupation Classification matrix
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description:
Employment and Social Development Canada has reported that:

On January 31, 2012, [ESDC] and Statistics Canada replaced the 2006 edition of the National Occupation Classification (NOC) with a 2011 version.

item.title: More temporary workers, and a modest proposal
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: As a response to an ever increasing number of temporary foreign workers in Canada, one BC group is proposing to let them in as permanent residents straightaway when they land.

item.title: Focus on Quebec’s female immigrants
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: More financial and other types of support are being pledged for Quebec’s female immigrants.

item.title: Provincial Nominee Programs working well
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Canada’s Provincial Nominee Immigration Programs (PNPs) continue to be successful according to a new report released today by Citizenship and Immigration Canada (CIC).

item.title: Happy Chinese New Year
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description:
Yesterday was the beginning of the Chinese New Year which will be celebrated for fifteen day in communicaties across Canada.

For the next two weeks the Chinese New Year will be celebrated in communities across Canada.

item.title: More immigrant support in Southern Ontario
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Immigrants to the Kitchener-Waterloo region of Ontario now have more support available to them. The Immigration Partnership Council was recently announced, which according to the Kitchener-Waterloo Record, will “better assist new immigrants become part of the community.”

item.title: Websites to help recognize foreign credentials
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: The Canadian government has announced a new website, available now, that will help in the recognition of foreign credentials for newcomers to Canada. This comes on the back of a similar initiative announced recently from the government of Quebec specifically geared towards engineers.

item.title: Immigration ups Manitoba’s population
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Manitoba has seen its second biggest increase in population since records began, at least in part due to immigration. Its Provincial Nominee Program (PNP) is the main driver of immigrants to the province, accounting for more than three quarters of new Canadian permanent residents arriving in Manitoba.

item.title: Canada has most multicultural workplaces
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: A new study by the Association for Canadian Studies (ACS) shows that Canada has the most multicultural workplaces of the four countries analyzed, being Canada, the United States, England, and France.

item.title: Calgary boomtown for immigration
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: With the fastest growing immigrant population in Canada, and the country’s first Muslim mayor, Calgary is poised to reap the rewards of Alberta’s energy boom for a wide spectrum of Canadians, including many of its newcomers.

item.title: Harper on immigration
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Prime Minister Stephen Harper is signalling more changes to Canada’s immigration policy are in store.

item.title: Happy Holidays
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: We want to wish all of our readers and clients, at CanadaVisa.com, and Cohen Immigration Law, happy holidays and a fruitful new year.

item.title: Recognizing engineers' foreign credentials will get easier in Quebec with new online tool
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: A new online tool will be deployed by the Quebec government to help immigrant engineers as they seek to become members of the Order of Engineers of Quebec and have their credentials recognized in the province.

item.title: Recognizing engineers' foreign credentials will get easier in Quebec with new online tool
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: A new online tool will be deployed by the Quebec government to help immigrant engineers as they seek to become members of the Order of Engineers of Quebec and have their credentials recognized in the province.

item.title: Newfoundland and Labrador, another province in need of skilled labour
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Like other provinces in Canada, notably Saskatchewan, Alberta, and British Columbia out west, Canada’s easternmost province, Newfoundland and Labrador, is also in the midst of an energy and resources boom that is taxing its ability to provide the skilled labour to complete planned projects.

item.title: Live-in caregivers can now get work permits significantly sooner
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Foreigners in Canada under the Live-in Caregiver Program (LCP) can now receive open work permits immediately after completing their caregiver commitments, and submitting an application for permanent residence (PR).

item.title: BC looking to boost skilled worker immigration
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: British Columbia’s government has created a task force to look at ways to boost skilled immigration to the province.

item.title: Destination Saskatchewan
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: With an economy that is the best in Canada, and an unemployment rate near the lowest in the country, Saskatchewan is quickly becoming a hot destination for temporary workers, immigrants, and others.

item.title: Montreal the only hip city in North America
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Montreal recently made the New York Times list of globally hip cities — the only one in North America, alongside such luminaries as Shanghai, Berlin, and Barcelona.

item.title: Tests now required for language points under Quebec Skilled Worker program
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: As of December 5th, new candidates to the Quebec Skilled Worker program who want to receive points for language for French and/or English, will have to submit test results along with their application.

item.title: Some no longer must submit passports once granted permanent residence
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: A final step during the application for Canadian permanent resident status, submitting your passport to the visa office so it can be stamped, is no longer necessary for citizens from Visitor Visa exempt countries.

item.title: CIC moves online
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Citizenship and Immigration Canada will be moving more of its business progressively online, says Minister Jason Kenney, with impending changes to include the ceasing of the printing and mailing out of forms and application kits starting December 1<sup>st</sup>.

item.title: Settlement funding helping new Canadians across the country
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: The amount of money the federal government allocates to provinces to help in the settlement of new immigrants has expanded significantly in the last half-decade, and is being spread more accurately to reflect their destinations within Canada.

item.title: Alberta tops in North America for economic freedom
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: According to new report by the Fraser Institute, Alberta is the most economically free jurisdiction in North America, topping all other provinces and states, based on data from 2009.

item.title: Alberta tops in North America for economic freedom
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: According to new report by the Fraser Institute, Alberta is the most economically free jurisdiction in North America, topping all other provinces and states, based on data from 2009.

item.title: Irish influx to Canada, more to come
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: It is estimated that around 10,000 Irishmen and women have relocated to Canada in the past two years, with the Canadian Ambassador to Ireland, Loyola Hearn, quoting much higher numbers possible in the near future.

item.title: Expansion of British Columbia PNP means more say for immigrant selection
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: British Columbia is likely to see more than 5000 immigrants get permanent residency under its Provincial Nominee Program (PNP) in 2012.

item.title: Latin American immigration to Canada on the rise
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Immigration from Latin American countries to Canada has risen by 121% between 1996 and 2006.

item.title: Immigrant and English-speaking growth in Laval — north of Montreal
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Above Canada’s second largest city, Montreal, sits Laval, also an island-bound city, that has become Quebec’s fastest growing English-speaking community, and home to many of its immigrants.

item.title: Canada celebrates Remembrance Day
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Today, November 11<sup>th</sup>, Canada celebrates Rememberance Day, like the rest of the Commonwealth countries, which recalls the end of World War I, on this day, in 1918.

item.title: Refugee immigration to Canada to be reduced
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: While there is humanitarian justification, as well as has been proven an economic benefit, the Canadian government plans to cap new refugee claims under the private sponsorship program, under the justification of reducing a growing backlog.

item.title: Record proportion of immigrants spread through Canada via PNP
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: More immigrants are beginning their settlement in Canada spread throughout the country via the Provincial Nomination Program (PNP).

item.title: New sponsorship applications for parents and grandparents on hold for two years
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: The Government of Canada has placed a two year moratorium on the Family Class program for parents and grandparents. As of November 5, 2011, no new sponsorship applications will be accepted for that specific category of the Family Class program.

item.title: New sponsorship applications for parents and grandparents on hold for two years
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: The Government of Canada has placed a two year moratorium on the Family Class program for parents and grandparents. As of November 5, 2011, no new sponsorship applications will be accepted for that specific category of the Family Class program.

item.title: 10,000 more skilled workers coming to Canada next year
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Next year, up to 10,000 additional immigrants will be allowed into Canada under the Federal Skilled Workers program.

item.title: Canada to accept more foreign students as permanent residents
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: The Government of Canada will be accepting up to 1,000 international PhD students as permanent residents through the Federal Skilled Worker (FSW) program per year.

item.title: Easing the transition for foreign-trained doctors
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: The Royal College of Physicians and Surgeons of Canada is suggesting ways for the federal government to ease the transition for foreign-trained doctors to set up shop in Canada.

item.title: Canadian immigration numbers for 2012 to be announced
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: This week, Citizenship and Immigration Minister Jason Kenney will be unveiling the 2012 Immigration Action Plan. According to an early statement made by Kenney, immigration levels will stay around 250,000 newcomers a year.

item.title: Conditional spousal sponsorship visas to be introduced
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: The Government of Canada will soon be announcing conditional visas for those sponsored under Canada’s Family Class Spousal Sponsorship Program in attempt to curb marriage fraud. There was speculation that this change would be considered, but Canadian officials are now confirming that the conditional visa will be introduced later this year.

item.title: Study shows Canadians still supportive of immigration
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: A recently released study regarding immigration found that Canadians are still supportive of immigration. The study, which was released by Montreal’s Institute for Research on Public Policy (IRPP) found that Canada continues to be a welcoming place for newcomers, with the many Canadians showing support for high levels of immigration.

item.title: Canadian government may reduce immigration numbers
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Canadian immigration processing times are increasing as a backlog of applications is building up at visa offices. Minister of Citizenship, Immigration and Multiculturalism Jason Kenney suggested that a simple solution may exist – decrease the number of applications Canada accepts from people wanting to join their families in Canada.

item.title: Canada celebrates Citizenship Week
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: From October 17 to 23 Canada celebrates Citizenship Week. This celebration attracts over 4,000 people from across Canada to participate in activities to reflect on citizenship and Canadian values. More than 60 Canadian citizenship ceremonies are taking place around the country where Canadians will reaffirm their commitment to Canada.

item.title: Long-haul truck drivers now permanent for British Columbia PNP
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: British Columbia has revised its Provincial Nominee Program (PNP) to permanently include long-haul truck drivers as part of its program. Previously, long-haul truck drivers were considered under a pilot project program.

item.title: Canadian government refocusing resettlement efforts
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Canada has put an end to an ineffective refugee program in order to put more efforts into working with the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) and refugees in greatest need of Canadian help.

item.title: Canada is top global destination for business
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Forbes has ranked Canada number one as the top destination in the world for business. Canada moved up from number four last year, thanks to a higher score in the tax category.

item.title: New Canadians get free access to cultural institutions
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Thanks to a unique Canadian program, new Canadian citizens are offered a free 12-month entrance pass to attractions across the country. The program is called the Cultural Access Pass, CAP, and is managed by the Institute for Canadian Citizenship. The program is quickly gaining popularity. Three years ago, only six facilities participated. Now, the program enrols 80 citizens a day with over 1,000 attractions across the country.

item.title: An Ontario county welcomes immigrants
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: An Ontario community, Simcoe County, is welcoming immigrants with open arms. The county is one of 45 in Ontario that has been asked by Citizenship and Immigration Canada to host a partnership aimed at analyzing the needs of current residents and newcomers.

item.title: Immigration is key for Canada’s economy
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: The Government of Canada views immigration as one of the most important factors in strengthening the economy following the recession and has noted that changes may come to the Temporary Foreign Worker Program.

item.title: Canada ranked one of best countries in the world for women
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: A recent compilation of rankings by the U.S. website Newsweek found Canada to be the third-best country in the world to be a woman.

item.title: Canada signs Protocol to fight anti-Semitism
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Canada has become the first country to sign the Ottawa Protocol on Combating Anti-Semitism. The Protocol, which developed during the Interparliamentary Coalition for Combating Anti-Semitism (ICCA) in Ottawa last year, is aimed at stopping hatred and discrimination, including anti-Semitism.

item.title: Montreal’s growing gaming industry attracting IT employees
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: According to Investissement Quebec, an economic development agency, 86 companies and more than 8,000 jobs have moved to Montreal as a result of a government program. The program allows 37.5 percent of a video-game company’s payroll to be subsidized by Montreal in the form of a refundable tax credit.

item.title: Study finds skilled immigrants highest earners for immigrants in Canada
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: A recent study on Canadian immigration policies has found that immigrants who move to Canada as independent skilled immigrants had the highest earnings of four categories of immigrants studied: independent primary skilled immigrants, accompanying economic immigrants, family class immigrants, and refugees.

item.title: Improvements made for Latin American travellers to Canada
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Diane Ablonczy, Minister of State and Foreign Affairs (Americans and Consular Affairs), recently announced improvements to make Canada more easily accessible for Latin American travellers.

item.title: McGill University ranked best in Canada
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: According to the new QS World University Rankings, Montreal’s McGill University is the top-ranked university in the country. McGill moved up from 19th place last year to 17th place worldwide this year.

item.title: Special Feature to be added to CICNews!
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Beginning next month, CICNews.com will be adding a new Q&A feature to its monthly newsletter. Readers will have the opportunity to send in their Canadian immigration questions to be answered by Attorney David Cohen.

item.title: Canada wants your input regarding immigration
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Citizenship and Immigration Canada (CIC) launched their online consultations regarding the appropriate level of immigration and mixes between economic, family class, and protected persons (refugees).

item.title: Alberta has highest earnings in Canada
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: According to Statistics Canada, Alberta had the highest weekly earnings in Canada this sumemr. The agency also noted that Alberta has the highest annual growth rate in the country.

item.title: More Indian students heading to Canadian universities
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: The University of Alberta recently announced that they are welcoming more Indian students than ever. Indian students seeking high-quality education at inexpensive costs are looking abroad, especially to Canada.

item.title: StatsCan – Canadian labour growth declining
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: A recent labour study conducted by Statistics Canada showed that Canada’s labour force is declining, especially in certain provinces like New Brunswick. Canada’s labour force participation rate is expected to be between 59 percent and 62 percent by 2031. The labour force participation rate last year was 67 percent.

item.title: British Columbia attracts more working families
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Citizenship, Immigration and Multiculturalism Minister Jason Kenney recently announced a pilot project aimed at attracting more working families to British Columbia. The pilot project will allow family members of most temporary foreign workers to work for any employer in the province.

item.title: Saskatchewan preparing for doctor shortage
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: The province of Saskatchewan, like most of Canada, is already experiencing a shortage of doctors and with the aging population, more shortages are expected. In response to the shortage, Saskatchewan employment recruiters are looking outside of Canada for the cure.

item.title: Research important when preparing to immigrate to Canada
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Doing research and being mentally prepared are very important for newcomers to Canada. A recent Royal Bank poll found that more than 58 percent of Chinese and South Asian immigrants said that emotional preparedness is the key to adjusting to a new life in Canada.

item.title: Canada’s unemployment rate falls as more jobs are added
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Last month, Canada’s unemployment rate fell to 7.2 percent from 7.4 percent in June, two percentage points lower than the United States. While economic forecasts predicted that 15,000 jobs would be added in July, 25,000 new full-time positions were created, aiding in the drop of the unemployment rate.

item.title: Canadian Immigration Minister wishes for a peaceful Ramadan
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Canada has long been home to many Muslim immigrants. According to the 2006 Census, there were close to 1 million Muslims living in Canada. The majority of Muslim immigrants live in the province of Ontario, with the larger groups settled around Toronto. Immigrants of all religious backgrounds choose to immigrate to Canada as there is no official religious discrimination according to the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms.

item.title: Survey shows Canadian employers hiring more
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: According to two indexes released this week, Canadian employers are steadily increasing recruitment. The Monster Employment Index showed that online recruitment in the second-quarter of this year was at its highest level since 2008. The Association of Canadian Search, Employment and Staffing Services (ACSESS) also showed that increased employment opportunities has brought the Canadian employment industry to near pre-recession levels.

item.title: Applicants reminded to use new Canadian Immigration forms
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: As of July 18, 2011, applicants who are applying for Canadian permanent residence are encouraged to use the new set of immigration forms: Generic Application Form for Canada (IMM 0008) and Schedule A – Background/Declaration (IMM 5669).

item.title: Easier way to travel to Canada: Ten-year multiple-entry visa
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Minister of Citizenship, Immigration and Multiculturalism, Jason Kenney, announced today that Canada will shortly be introducing a ten-year multiple entry visa.

item.title: Alberta wants temporary foreign workers to stay in Canada
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Thomas Lukaszuk, Alberta’s Minister of Immigration and Employment, is urging the federal government to allow more than 30,000 temporary foreign workers in the province to settle in Canada permanently.

item.title: McGill University ranks No. 1 in Canada, 12th in world
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: A new QS World University Ranking placed Quebec’s McGill University’s law faculty as 12th best in the world and number one in Canada. Rankings were based on academic opinion, employer opinion, and citations by academics.

item.title: Ottawa may make it easier for travellers with DUI records to enter Canada
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: The Canadian government is discussing ways to make it easier for Americans with convictions for driving under the influence (DUI) to enter Canada. The federal government has been receiving numerous complaints that border officials are not allowing Americans to enter Canada because of former DUI convictions. Statistics provided by the Canada Border Services Agency (CBSA) show that 6,948 Americans were denied entry into Canada on the basis of criminality.

item.title: Canada looks ahead to impending labour shortages
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: The Government of Canada has launched a website to help Canadians identify which job sectors are hiring and which sectors are likely to experience growth in the future.

item.title: Why it’s great to be in Canada
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: In celebration of Canada Day, MacLeans has released a report of the things that makes Canada a great nation. From large housing to an advanced medical research programs, there are many reasons why immigrants should choose to settle in Canada.

item.title: Happy Canada Day!
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Today, Canada celebrates its 144th birthday! Canada Day, celebrated every July 1st, is a national holiday that marks the anniversary of the July 1, 1867 enactment of the British North America Act. This act brought three separate British colonies (Nova Soctia, New Brunswick, and the Province of Canada) together to form one country: Canada.

item.title: Alberta launches tool to evaluate foreign credentials
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: The province of Alberta has launched a free online tool, the Education Overview Guide, to help employers better understand the educational credentials of immigrants seeking to work in Alberta.

item.title: Canada cracking down on crooked immigration consultants
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Citizenship, Immigration and Multiculturalism Minister Jason Kenney announced today that legislation regarding immigration consultants will come into effect on June 30, 2011.

item.title: Breaking News: Changes to Canadian Federal Immigration Programs
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Citizenship and Immigration Canada (CIC) has just announced changes to the Federal Skilled Worker Program, Federal Immigrant Investor Program and the Federal Entrepreneur Program.

item.title: Job-seekers head to Alberta
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Increasing job opportunities in Alberta have many Canadians moving to the province. More than 5,300 Canadians moved to Alberta between January and the end of March compared to only 300 during the same time period last year.

item.title: Government of Canada celebrates World Refugee Day
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: To mark World Refugee Day, Citizenship, Immigration and Multiculturalism Minister Jason Kenney launched a new exhibit and Youtube video that demonstrates the hardships experienced by refugees and explains how Canada is helping them.

item.title: Canada prepares to introduce biometric scanning for immigrants
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: The Canadian government will soon require immigrants to undergo biometric scanning in order to enter the country in order to improve border security. This technology has been used for years by other Western countries to reduce the instances of immigration fraud.

item.title: Canada announces new 10-year visa for Indians
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: The Government of Canada recently announced a 10-year multiple entry visa that will now be available for Indian citizens. The new visa is hoped to boost trade ties between Canada and India by tripling their trade to $15 billion within four years.

item.title: Canadian universities strengthen ties with India
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: In 2008, more than 160,000 Indian students were studying abroad, but only 4,000 of them were in Canada. Canada is looking to change those numbers by playing a larger role in India’s desire for higher education.

item.title: More Asian immigrants are choosing to settle in Vancouver
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Once dominated by British, German, and Italian immigrants, Vancouver’s population can now be considered “Eurasian” as thousands of Asians immigrants now call the city their home.

item.title: Time running out to apply under current Federal Skilled Worker Program
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: In less than one month, Citizenship and Immigration Canada (CIC) will be announcing the new list of qualifying occupations for the Federal Skilled Worker program. Currently, applicants must have at least one year of skilled work experience in one of the 29 open occupations or have valid job offer from a Canadian employer.

item.title: Canada needs 100,000 more immigrants a year
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: A former Canadian Immigration Director has stated that Canada needs to increase its annual immigration intake by 100,000 a year to match needed population targets. Robert Vineberg, former Director of Federal-Provincial Relations at Immigration Canada, is calling for policy changes in order to boost immigration numbers in most provinces.

item.title: Taipei visa office to close in June
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Citizenship and Immigration Canada recently released a bulletin stating that the Canadian visa office in Taipei, Taiwan will no longer be accepting new applications.

item.title: Canadians happy and comfortable shows study
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: According to the Better Life Index, created by the Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development, Canada placed second out of 34 counties for having the best quality of life.

item.title: Toronto program turning Indian immigrants into millionaires
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Struggling Indian immigrants are getting help from a Toronto program aimed at turning them into successful entrepreneurs.

item.title: Alberta successfully attracting immigrants
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: According to the Alberta Immigration Progress Report 2011, over the past five years, Alberta has successfully implemented programs to help immigrants find jobs which meet their skills and experience.

item.title: Job prospects on the rise in Canada
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Last month, Canada added more than 58,000 jobs to the workforce. According to a report by Statistics Canada, the national unemployment rate has decreased by 0.1 percent to 7.6 percent.

item.title: Foreign-trained nurses get helping hand by Canadian agency
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: More than 10 percent of Ontario’s registered and practical nurses have received their training from outside of Canada. Creating Access to Regulated Employment, or CARE, was created to help these nurses get accredited to work in Canada.

item.title: Nova Scotia wants more immigrants
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: By 2020, the province of Nova Scotia hopes to double the number of immigrants arriving in their province per year.

item.title: Workers needed in Alberta
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Alberta will soon be experiencing a shortage of more than 77,000 workers within the next ten years, according to Employment Minister Thomas Lukaszuk.

item.title: B.C. rally against fraudulent consultants
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Dozens of people gathered in Surrey, British Columbia on Sunday to speak out against immigration fraud and fraudulent consultants.

item.title: British name Canada best place to live
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: According to a recent study of more than 1,000 British living abroad, Canada is considered to be the best place to live and offers the best quality of life for British citizens living abroad.

item.title: Want to become a millionaire? Canada’s the place to do it.
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Rather than inheriting money, many wealthy Canadians are now earning their fortunes on their own.

item.title: Canadians most tolerant
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: A report released by the Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development concluded that Canada is the most tolerant country of the 140 countries polled.

item.title: Study: Why Canada needs more immigrants
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: A recent study conducted by Tony Fang, a Canadian professor at the University of York in Vancouver, found that Canada needs to increase the number of immigrants coming to Canada in order to encourage investment in housing and to help boost the nation’s economy.

item.title: More women becoming entrepreneurs in Canada
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Statistics Canada has indicated that there are over 826,000 women who are entrepreneurs in Canada. The number of self-employed women in Canada has increased by 50%.

item.title: Canada’s IT industry to face labour shortages
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: A recent report, entitled Outlook for Human Resources in the ICT Labour Market, 2011-2016, states that there will be a labour shortage of qualified applicants for IT related jobs in Canada within the next few years. The report was released by the Information and Communications Technology Council (ICTC).

item.title: Saskatchewan settlement group proving popular
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Saskatchewan currently has 11 settlement agencies in the province. One of those agencies is Estevan Comprehensive School. Estevan is located in southeast Saskatchewan and is currently serving over 55 different communities.

item.title: Proposed changes for spousal sponsorships
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: As Citizenship and Immigration Canada (CIC) and the Government of Canada have noticed an increase in the number of fraudulent marriages, they are proposing changes for the Family Class immigration category, specifically for spousal sponsorships.

item.title: Training program helping Ontario immigrants
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Jason Kenney, Immigration and Multiculturalism Minister, recently announced that the Government of Canada will provide $22 million to fund the Bridge Training Program. The training program is aimed at helping skilled immigrants better integrate into the Canadian labour market.

item.title: Consultation for Federal Skilled Worker Program extended
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Citizenship and Immigration Canada (CIC) has been consulting with relevant stakeholders on the proposed changes to the Federal Skilled Worker Program. Due to the high volume of responses, CIC has decided to extend the consultation period until March 31.

item.title: New pilot project to help refugees
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Citizenship and Immigration Canada (CIC) has launched a pilot project aimed at helping refugees who are escaping persecution due to their sexual orientation. CIC will be partnering with Rainbow Refugee Committee, a Vancouver-based organization, to share the costs involved with sponsoring refugees.

item.title: Philippines – Canada’s largest source of immigrants
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: China and India have been Canada’s largest source of immigrants for years, but the trends are changing. Earlier this year, the Philippines surpassed China and India, becoming Canada’s number one source of immigrants.

item.title: Canada contributes $10M to Egyptian youth projects
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Foreign Affairs Minister Lawrence Cannon recently announced that will contribute almost $11 million to foster democratic institutions projects in Egypt and the surrounding boarder regions.

item.title: Canadian Citizenship Guide updated
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Jason Kenney, Minister of Citizenship, Immigration and Multiculturalism, recently announced that the Canadian Citizenship study guide has been updated to include more information about Canada. The updated guide, Discover Canada: the Rights and Responsibilities of Citizenship, can now be ordered or downloaded from Citizenship and Immigration Canada’s website, www.cic.gc.ca

item.title: Alberta’s economy continues to grow
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: A report from RBC Economics has indicated that Alberta’s economy will grow by 4.3% in 2011. Alberta is expected to have the third highest economic growth in Canada after Saskatchewan and Newfoundland and Labrador.

item.title: New P.E.I. programs introduced
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Prince Edward Island has introduced five new streams into their Provincial Nominee Program, which are active immediately. The Skilled Worker Stream and the Family Connection Stream still remain part of the program.

item.title: P.E.I. welcoming Chinese immigrants
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Prince Edward Island recently hosted the Chinese Islanders Business Summit, in which they welcomed over 200 new Chinese immigrants to the province.

item.title: Helping youths prepare for the Canadian job market
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: The Government of Canada announced their support for an employment project, entitled the Skilled Link program. Skills Link is aimed at helping youths prepare to enter the Canadian work force by providing job preparation training and work experience.

item.title: New rules for Canadian employers and foreign workers
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: On April 1, Citizenship and Immigration Canada (CIC) will announce new regulations for Canadian employers looking to hire foreign workers. The new regulations will cover various aspects of hiring foreign workers, such as the amount of time a job offer is valid to the actual terms of a work permit.

item.title: Multicultural women celebrated by Calgary event
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: As part of International Women’s Day, Calgary will be holding a special event celebrating women from different cultures. The special event, entitled “Celebrating the Roles of Multicultural Women”, will be partially funded by Citizenship and Immigration Canada (CIC).

item.title: Study shows Canada excels at integrating immigrants
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: In a survey of countries in Europe and North America, Canada was found to be better at integrating immigrants into society compared to most other countries.

item.title: Improved social housing and job creation in Quebec
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: The Government of Canada has announced that nearly $9 million will be given to 116 housing cooperatives and non-profit organizations in Quebec. The funds will be used for social housing renovations and for new investments.

item.title: Survey names Vancouver world’s most liveable city
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: An annual survey conducted by the Economist Intelligence Unit has named Vancouver, British Columbia the most liveable city in the world. Vancouver has maintained the number one position for the past five years.

item.title: Canada celebrates Family Day
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: The third Monday in February is known as Family Day in the provinces of Alberta, Ontario and Saskatchewan. Held for the first time in 1990 in Alberta, Family Day is celebrated as a day to recognize the importance of family.

item.title: Study shows immigrants with apprenticeships earn more in Canada
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: A recent study by the University of New Brunswick and Carleton University has discovered that immigrants who have completed an apprenticeship have a higher salary than immigrants with a high school degree alone.

item.title: Hockey Canada recruiting immigrant children
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Studies have shown that Canada’s population is not increasing on its own and the number of children from ages five to 19 has been decreasing. Immigration is one of the main sources for population growth in Canada. Hockey Canada has recognized this fact and is now targeting young newcomers to Canada.

item.title: Canada hits record numbers for immigration in 2010
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Last year, Canada admitted the highest number of immigrants in over 50 years. 280,636 immigrants became permanent residents of Canada in 2010, more than 6% of what was originally expected. Most of the newcomers were skilled workers.

item.title: P.E.I. to introduce new investor immigration program
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: In about one month, Prince Edward Island will be introducing a new investor program into their Provincial Nominee Program. The province had an investor program from 2001 to 2008, but this new program will have some important changes.

item.title: Alberta offers advice to immigrant parents
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: The province of Alberta has created a new program designed specifically for immigrants with young children. Alberta Health Services is now offering a 23-part audio series in five different languages. Information for the program was gathered from public-health nurses and workers who practice within immigrant communities.

item.title: Canadian jobs soar above expectations
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Economists had predicted that 15,000 people would join the Canadian workforce in January 2011. According to a recent announcement by Statistics Canada, almost 70,000 people were added to the workforce in Canada last month, almost five times the amount originally predicted.

item.title: Immigration viewed more positively in Canada than in Europe and the U.S.
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Participants from Canada, the United States, the United Kingdom, France, Germany, Italy, the Netherlands and Spain, were polled on a wide array of immigration issues. According to the recent poll, Canadians viewed immigration more positively than Americans and Europeans.

item.title: Ontario launches Brain Gain pilot project
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Ontario recently launched a pilot project, entitled Brain Gain, to assist spouses and dependents of certain Canadians to work in Ontario while their applications for permanent residency are in process.

item.title: New Brunswick encouraging immigrant entrepreneurs
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Fredericton, the capital of New Brunswick, is helping new immigrant entrepreneurs by promoting the Fredericton Business Immigrant Mentorship Program. The program was created specifically for immigrants who wish to invest in the local business community. The program originally began in 2009 and has since been successful at pairing new immigrants with mentors from various professional fields, such as accounting and finance, business marketing, professional sales and investment.

item.title: Child immigrants more likely to obtain university degrees than Canadian children
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: According to new research from Statistics Canada, children of immigrants are more likely than Canadian-born children to earn university degrees. Statistics Canada also found that child immigrants earn approximately the same amount of money as Canadian-born children once they are in the labour market.

item.title: Study finds more immigrants are choosing Atlantic Canada
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: A recent study by Saint Mary’s University has found that immigrants who settle in the Atlantic Provinces (Prince Edward Island, Nova Scotia, New Brunswick, and Newfoundland and Labrador) do better professionally than immigrants who choose to settle in more popular destinations, such as Toronto and Vancouver.

item.title: Helping immigrants integrate into the Canadian workforce
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: A Vancouver pilot project was launched this week in order to help skilled immigrants better integrate into the Canadian business world. The Newcomer’s Mentorship Program is a joint project between the city of Vancouver and S.U.C.C.E.S.S., which is an organization for newcomers to Canada.

item.title: Increasing number of Irish immigrants expected to arrive in Canada
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Due to Ireland’s current economic situation, many Irish are choosing to move to Canada in hopes of a better future and for financial security. Canada has seen an 80% increase in the number of Irish people immigrating to the country since 2007. The number of immigrants arriving from Ireland is expected to rise even higher in the coming years.

item.title: British Columbia project aimed at hiring immigrants
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: By 2015 more than 1 million jobs will be available in Canada due to the aging population. As Canada has a low birth-rate, there will not be enough workers to replace the soon-to-be retiring employees. Embracing Cultural Diversity in the B.C. Workplace, funded by the Province of British Columbia, is a project aimed at informing employers of the benefits of hiring immigrants.

item.title: Haitian children reunited with Canadian adoptive parents
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Last year the Government of Haiti gave permission for 250 Haitian children to be adopted by Canadian families in a project entitled Operation Stork. Since the beginning of the project, 203 children have been adopted. 152 of those children have already become permanent residents or citizens of Canada.

item.title: Montreal sending experts to assist Haiti with urban planning
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: One year after the devastating earthquake hit Haiti, the country is still in desperate need of foreign assistance. Canada has donated over $400 million to aid Haiti in rebuilding their country, but more than just money is needed.

item.title: Immigrant youths fighting discrimination
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Citizenship and Immigration Canada will be granting $905,000 to the city of Vancouver for a three year project entitled CitizenU. The project will consist of 2,000 at-risk youth, ages 15-20, from diverse ethnic backgrounds who will speak out against discrimination and bullying in their community.

item.title: 22,000 new jobs added to Canadian labour market in December
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Canada’s unemployment rate has decreased to approximately 7.6% as a result of additional jobs being added to the labour market, matching the number of Canadians entering the labour force.

item.title: Manitoba provides affordable housing to new immigrants
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: The Government of Canada and the province of Manitoba are investing $9 million to renovate old housing units in Winnipeg for new immigrants. Immigrant and Refugee Community Organization of Manitoba (IRCOM) will be overseeing the management of properties once the project is complete. One of the main goals of IRCOM is to provide immigrants with affordable housing in addition to providing settlement services.

item.title: Why more people are choosing to move to Canada
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: In the past, the United States was considered a top destination for immigrants looking for a better life. Since 2007, the US economy has been greatly unstable, meaning immigrants, including Americans, are looking for a land with better opportunities. Canada is quickly growing in popularity and for good reasons.

item.title: Immigrants are hard workers according to Saskatchewan study
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: A recent poll from Sigma Analytics indicated that a majority of Saskatchewan residents agree or strongly agreed that immigrants are hard workers who contribute to the Canadian economy.

item.title: More permanent residents wanted in Manitoba
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: In 2010, Manitoba experienced a 17% increase in the number of immigrants arriving in the province. It is estimated that over 15,000 permanent residents arrived in Manitoba this past year.

item.title: Immigrants now choosing Prince Edward Island
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Prince Edward Island was once considered a mostly homogenous society. Most immigrants arriving in Canada chose to settle in more popular areas, such as Toronto, Montreal, and Vancouver. Recent statistics show that this trend is now changing.

item.title: Reuniting a family – a holiday gift from Canadians
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Sponsored to come to Canada as a nanny, Elenor Diaz immigrated to Canada from the Philippines in 2006 and became a Canadian permanent resident in 2009. She has been working three jobs to save enough money to bring her family to Canada for Christmas and to begin a sponsorship application to permanently settle her family in Canada.

item.title: Increased immigrant-settlement funding for Alberta
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Due to higher numbers of immigrants settling in the province of Alberta, the government of Canada has decided to increase funding for settlement agencies in the province. It is expected that Alberta will receive over $64 million in order to assist immigrants settle into their new Canadian communities.

item.title: Canadian Jobs in 2011
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: As Canada’s economy continues to strengthen, more jobs are being added every day. While the service industry continues to dominate the Canadian economy, there are other sectors that will be adding even more jobs in the coming year.

item.title: Canada ranked 6th in a recent international survey of education
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: According to a survey of international schools conducted by the Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development, Canada was found to have some of the highest performing students in the world. Students from countries such as China, Australia, Finland, Japan, Canada and more were tested on mathematical and reading skills and their knowledge of the sciences.

item.title: Immigration important for Canada’s population growth
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: According to Statistics Canada, the population of Canada has grown by more than 129,300 people from July 2010 to October 2010. More than 65% of those people were new immigrants to the country. Within those 3 months, 84,200 new immigrants arrived in Canada. This growth in immigration can be attributed to the strengthening Canadian economy. As new jobs are being added to the market, Canada is looking for skilled workers to immigrate to the country. The Government of Canada is expecting to issue approximately 265,000 Canadian visas by the end of this year.

item.title: Welcoming Indian students to Canada
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Recent statistics reveal that the number of applicants applying for a Canadian student visas from India has quadrupled in the last three years. It is estimated that over 20,000 student visas will be issued to Indian students in 2011.

item.title: Protecting immigrants from crooked consultants
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: The Government of Canada has recently introduced new legislation in order to protect immigrants against fraudulent immigration consultants, sometimes known as “ghost” consultants. This legislation aims to ensure that only authorized lawyers, notaries, and consultants who are in good standing with a Canadian provincial or territorial law society may charge fees for immigration applications. If a consultant who is not authorized attempts to provide immigration advice or represent a client for a fee, this “ghost” consultant can face criminal charges.

item.title: Nova Scotia welcoming French-speaking immigrants
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Many French-speaking immigrants choose to settle in the province of Quebec as French is widely spoken throughout the province. French-speaking immigrants who choose to settle in other provinces often have difficulties integrating into a mainly English workforce.

item.title: Canada’s growing nursing workforce
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: According to a recent survey conducted by the Canadian Institute for Health Information, Canada now has around 350,000 regulated nurses across the country. Since 2005, approximately 30,000 nurses joined the Canadian work force. About 75% of those nurses are registered nurses, followed closely by licensed practical nurses, who have experienced the highest growth rate in the nursing workforce.

item.title: More Chinese immigrants expected to settle in Alberta
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Over 1,000 new immigrants from China are expected to arrive in Calgary in the coming year. Today, there are approximately 75,000 people of Chinese origin settled in Calgary. This influx of Chinese immigrants is strengthening political, cultural, and commercial relations between China and Canada and in particular, Alberta.

item.title: Workers’ salaries continue to rise in Saskatchewan
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Since September 2009, salaries for workers in Saskatchewan have increased by almost five percent, making Saskatchewan the third highest paying province in Canada, after only Ontario and Alberta. This last September, the average earnings per week in Saskatchewan was almost $850, according to Statistics Canada.

item.title: Canada continues to assist Haiti in time of need
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: The Government of Canada has recently announced they will continue to aid Haiti in the rebuilding of their country. Due to the massive earthquake in January 2010 which devastated the country, Haiti is in desperate need of support to restore many essential services to its citizens.

item.title: Canada invests $2 million in Toronto to help newcomers
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Citizenship and Immigration Canada announced today that Canada is investing more than $2 million for improved access to services to help newcomers successfully integrate.

item.title: The secret to a successful career in Canada
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: A new report released December 1, 2010, has concluded that self-confidence and a can-do attitude are the main determinants to an immigrant's success in Canada. The report was authored by a psychology professor at UBC and an immigrant support group called SUCCESS, based in Vancouver.

item.title: Skilled worker immigrants doing well in Canada
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: A new evaluation has found that those who immigrant to Canada under the Federal Skilled Worker program are contributing to Canada's economy. According to the evaluation, the biggest predictors of an immigrant’s economic success are having a job already arranged in Canada when applying; the ability to speak English or French; and having worked in Canada before applying to immigrate.

item.title: Canada boycotts Durban commemorative event
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: The Government of Canada has announced it will not participate in the events to commemorate the 10th anniversary of the adoption of the Durban Declaration and Program of Action (DDPA) in September 2011. Citizenship and Immigration Minister Jason Kenney said, “Our government has lost faith in the Durban process. We will not be part of this event, which commemorates an agenda that promotes racism rather than combats it.”

item.title: Tips for settlement and finances in Canada
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: It may be very important for newcomers to Canada to manage their finances well. Understanding how banking and finance works in Canada will be a big advantage to potential new Canadian permanent residents. Many new Canadian permanent residents have difficulty accessing credit, which is very often needed to buy a car or a home.

item.title: Canada announces funding for Settlement Services in Sudbury
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: The Government of Canada is investing more than $220,000 to support the Newcomers Services program at the YMCA in Sudbury, Ontario. This funding, made available through Citizenship and Immigration Canada’s (CIC’s) Settlement Program. The YMCA will provide one-on-one support, career counselling, and referrals to community services for newcomers in Sudbury.

item.title: Canada hosts international conference on combating anti-Semitism
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: The second annual conference of the Inter-parliamentary Coalition for Combating Antisemitism (ICCA) opened yesterday in Ottawa, Canada. The Government of Canada is supporting the conference, which is bringing together representatives from more than 45 countries.

item.title: Record high number of job postings in Saskatchewan
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Saskatchewan's unemployment rate for October was just 5.7%, lower than the national unemployment rate, which is currently at 7.9%. Saskatchewan’s economy continues to fuel job creation—the number of job postings in Saskatchewan is higher now than at any other time during the past two years.

item.title: Canada keeps immigration levels steady for 2011
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: The Government of Canada will keep Canada's immigration levels the same next year, for 2011. The government says its goal is to take in between 240,000 and 265,000 new permanent residents next year—the same target as for 2009 and 2010. Immigration Minister Jason Kenney says, "Canada's post-recession economy demands a high level of legal immigration to keep our workforce strong.”

item.title: Iraqi refugee program extended to 2013
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: The Government of Canada has extended the Iraqi refugee program for an additional two years. Between 2011 and 2013, the Iraqi refugee program will allow an additional 8,600 refugees to resettle in Canada. This extension was announced on Saturday by Citizenship and Immigration Minister Jason Kenney.

item.title: Canada's Citizenship Week 2010: Celebrating Canadian Citizenship
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: This week is Canada's Citizenship Week 2010. It is a time for Canadians to reflect on what it means to be Canadian, and on the rights and responsibilities of citizenship. In 2009 alone, more than 155,000 newcomers to Canada became Canadian citizens, embracing the Canadian values of democracy, freedom, human rights and the rule of law.

item.title: Saskatchewan records highest employment numbers
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: The Canadian province of Saskatchewan recorded the highest employment numbers ever for the month of September. Overall, there 6,300 more jobs in the province compared to one year ago. "People are coming to Saskatchewan because they are confident in our economy and that prospects here are very good," said Rob Norris, Minster of Advanced Education, Employment and Immigration.

item.title: Most asylum seekers from Sri Lanka deemed legitimate by Canada
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: The government of Canada is considering ways to prevent migrant smuggling because of the arrival in August this year of a ship with almost 500 Sri Lankan asylum seekers on board; however, the Canadian refugee determination process was designed to deal with people seeking asylum by landing on Canada's shores, fleeing for their lives.

item.title: Quebec is the leader in job creation
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Quebec had the best performance in all of North America in terms of job creation. While jobs were lost in other parts of Canada during the month of September, more than 14,000 new jobs were created in Quebec. Since June 2009, more than 125,000 jobs have been created in Quebec, which means Quebec has created almost twice as many new jobs as were lost in the recession of 2008-2009.

item.title: Immigration boosts Saskatchewan population
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: In the last year, almost 50% of population growth in the province of Saskatchewan can be attributed to immigration. Statistics Canada is showing a record-breaking increase in Saskatchewan’s population, which now sits at just under 1,050,000. Saskatchewan's increase rate (+0.47%) was the second highest among all the Canadian provinces. It was Saskatchewan largest growth in population since the third quarter of 2007.

item.title: Government of Canada announced Federal Internship for Newcomers program
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: The Government of Canada announced yesterday it is launching the Federal Internship for Newcomers program designed to assist newcomers gain valuable Canadian work experience. Through this program, immigrants to Canada now have the opportunity to acquire some temporary work experience in fields they are qualified to work in based on their skills and previous work experience.

item.title: Ontario invests in training for skilled immigrants
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
item.description: Ontario is helping skilled newcomers prepare to get jobs that match their education, qualifications and experience. The Ontario provincial government is investing $3.6 million in three Ontario cities to support programs designed to train new skilled immigrants to find employment in their professions and areas of expertise.

item.title: Canada and Australia discuss issues related to human smuggling
item.author: webadmin@canadavisa.com (The CanadaVisa Team)
